text: I stay, but don’t push forward.
I don’t touch her battlefield—I only do the work she called “not getting in the way”: moving supplies, passing medicine, running errands, dragging the fallen to the rear.
The snow falls heavier. Mud and ice churn together underfoot, every step like sinking into freezing water. But the people at the north gate don’t stop.

The moment the medical kit opens, the sharp scent of disinfectant cuts through the blood in the air. Lucia kneels inside a makeshift shelter, fingers red with cold, yet she wraps each bandage tight and steady.
She looks up and sees me. Relief flickers in her eyes—then tightens again at once.
“So you really stayed…”
“I’m just carrying things. I’m not stepping forward.”
“Then take these to the shield line on the left.”
She shoves a pouch of clotting powder into my arms, quick—like if she slowed down, she’d start thinking too much.

I run past the supply piles and see a different kind of struggle: someone bracing a crate with their shoulder, someone retieing ropes stiff with frost, someone shielding a wounded man with a torn blanket.
No one shouts about heroes. Just short commands: “Here.” “Again.” “Hurry.”
From a distance, I see Alicia standing on the stone steps. She makes no wasted motion, yet the entire defense line tightens under her hands.
She points to the left flank—shields shift at once. She raises a hand—the archers on the right reposition. Not a word wasted.
That fluency isn’t ease—it’s fear pressed thin. So thin it can’t be seen.
I hand over the medicine and can’t help calling out, “Alicia!”
Her gaze lands on me, then quickly drops to the pouch in my hand, then to the ground at my feet—confirming I haven’t crossed the line.
“Good.”
She steps closer and pulls an old bronze badge from inside her cloak, pressing it into my hand.
“Keep it. Guarding the fire is harder than wielding a sword.”
The badge is cold at first, then slowly warms in my palm.
“I’m not in the way.”
“You’re already in my way—here.”
She says it plainly, briefly. Like she’s holding something down and will only let it surface this far.
“Go back.”
“It hasn’t even started—”
“It will.”
“I need you to keep the inn secure. Keep the fire burning. Bolt the door. If Lucia comes back, give her hot water.”
When she says “hot water,” her voice softens just slightly—as if she finally allows herself to admit someone might be afraid, cold, or unable to hold on.
“Will you come back?”
She doesn’t hesitate.
“I’ll try.”
Not a promise—just the fullest honesty she can offer.
She gestures me back again, placing me in the “safe position.” Then she turns and resumes directing the line, her silhouette clean and taut like a drawn bow.
I stand there, suddenly aware that my palms are slick with sweat. The wind cuts across them, cold and sharp.
I leave the north gate as she told me to. Looking back along the way, the defensive line grows into a thin, dark thread in the snow-fog.
When I reach the inn, the fire is still burning. But I can’t sit still.
That night, I don’t sleep. Every time the wind rises, I think it’s begun at the north gate.
